Params[3]: Lithos' interference has sent Noan back into the void between torment and rebirth.
He enters a very long dream, so long that it encompasses his whole life.
But that is only an instant in the river of time, lasting but 21 years in an age that does not seem to end.
In the infinite darkness is the sound of blood dripping. The absurd scenery scatters with the ripples, echoing in a fictitious dream.
The cries, whispers, and prayers of many form a chain that threatens to tear his soul apart.
After an extended struggle, his panicking body eventually stops resisting, and he lets the corpses drag him into the crimson ocean.
How many times has this process been repeated? To lose his memories before starting with a blank page again?
—Plop.
Fragments of his memories drip down his cheek alongside the trail of blood, and he hears a voice in his ears.
If you wish to become their accomplice in exchange for that power... it's a betrayal and an insult to those who lost their lives!
...Regret?
No, I don't regret anything...
What happened after they threw him off the train? His memory... is still incomplete.
Noan... Noan?
Wake up...
Good, you're okay...
...Field?
Where the hell did you go this time? You got cuts and bruises all over you!
Mom...
How are you doing?
Noan tries to move his body, only to discover that he is in so much pain he cannot even lift a finger.
I told you you should have given Ashlar the evidence.
...I'm sorry...
What do I say to your mother now that you've ended up like this?
Why won't you learn how to compromise? Ask people for help if you can't do it yourself.
...But you're all gone. Who do I ask?
Summer, Mom, Rachel... Aunt Hill... What should I... what should I do...?
What should... what should I do...
Help me...
You'll have to wake up first, Noan.
Is this a dream?
In my dream... you're all dead... Will everything get better if I wake up?
Looking at you being silly. That part isn't a dream.
Her words awake the dreamer like throwing ice water to his face.
His eyes open in the infinite darkness. Gasping for air, Noan is hit by the excruciating pain in his chest, and he groans in agony.
Hey! Doc! He's awake!
Lucky bastard.
Am I alive?
You bet. I saved you.
You wouldn't believe your fortune. The rope on you wrapped around a pillar after it snapped, cushioning your fall before you landed on a pile of snow.
And your toy firefly somehow blocked the shot to your chest...
You still broke a few ribs from the impact, though. Including your other injuries, you're probably spending the next three months in this hospital bed.
...Why did you save me?
The royals were partially responsible for the risk you took.
Leader wanted me to apologize to you on her behalf. She's not able to help you openly for now, and she couldn't bring any change to the lower level all these years despite her wish.
The person who started a fire shouldn't die in the cold. This is the least she can do for you.
I've paid for everything here. Rest up, get better, and wait for our good news.
Good news?
Leader said she wouldn't let everyone's sacrifice be in vain.
What will that do...? They're all...
There was this line from an old poem. Have you heard of it? "Earth, the travelers' tavern; lament, the travelers' song."
This is how I understand it: everything in this world comes to an end eventually. It's pointless to expect something at the end of your journey. The journey is the point.
It's up to you what you find in yours.
Oh. One more thing.
The young Construct leans down and whispers in Noan's ears.
I was in a hurry when I came down to save you. Ashlar might figure out that you're still alive.
I told the people in this base that you're just some random, innocent stranger lying on the road, and I offered some hush money to make sure the news doesn't get out. Still, watch out for yourself.
I've got to head back to Leader now. I'll see you when I see you.
...See you.
Noan waves goodbye feebly before falling asleep and dreaming again.
He dreams about an endless snowstorm. The ground is covered in blood, and human limbs can be found everywhere.
Noan is pursued by countless shadowy figures, and he tries to escape along a dark, narrow path.
Before he knows it, he suddenly falls, landing in a crimson swamp.
Noan finds himself growing a pair of wings that cannot fly. He struggles, his attempts futile and unsightly.
A legion of raging hands grabs his body, dragging him down into the infinite abyss.
—Being hunted, running away, then falling... The dream keeps repeating itself.
Noan will often wake up in the middle of the night in a panic, staring at the unfamiliar dark room that houses him.
Then he will fall asleep again from the pain of his unhealed wounds, revisiting the haunting nightmare.
After he realizes that he is the only person who dies in this dream, he starts to feel blissful about his torture and death in his nightmare.
Even a dream of thorns is better than the real world. The line between dream and reality starts to blur in the twilight hours.
He has no idea how long this cycle of waking and dreaming has lasted.
Having lost everything, he seeks the slightest hint of warmth in his dreams while allowing his body to be trapped in an extended slumber.
Only when he hears a baby crying inside a distant ward and visitors filling the space with the scent of food and sweat does Noan feels a warmness in the air.
The doctor chuckles while placing a blossoming flower by Noan's bed. That is when Noan realizes he has wasted a lot of time waiting and withering.
How is the train?
How long until the "good news" the young Construct mentioned?
He manages to sit on the hospital bed despite his condition and calls faintly for the staff member from the base who is passing by.
Excuse me... Is there news about Asslam recently?
You mean news about the incident?
Yes.
The official story was that it was a man-made disaster.
The Cargo Crew was discontent with the upper level's management and planned a riot.
A mole leaked the Cargo Crew's plan and forced their hand, so they had to blow up the train and caused the whole thing.
...That's the official story?
Yeah.
I heard the name of the mole was Assad. He stayed around their Chief Captain for over a decade to avenge his parents.
Guy picked quite the moment to leak their plan and took down the whole Cargo Crew with him.
You got it wrong—the mole's name was Noan. They didn't disclose it publicly, but I heard it from a guy on the Cargo Crew yesterday, so don't blame the wrong guy.
The Cargo Crew just started recruiting not too long ago. With that many new people in their ranks, I doubt everything you heard from them is accurate.
Who cares what the mole is called? What happened to him?
Some said he was dead, and some said he lived. If you've heard anything, you can even trade the information for supplies with the guards who're coming.
Giggling among themselves, the staff members walk away, leaving Noan alone. He wraps his light blanket around himself, mustering any warmth he can gather as he shivers.
Opening his eyes, he returns once again to the empty carriage.
The lingering light from the dusk coats the scenery outside the window, its presence wavering as the train marches ahead.
Everything here is more real than the real world.
How have you been lately?
Lately?
Yeah. You told me it was spring the last time you were here.
You said you had gotten better and found a temporary job at the base.
So? How have you been?
Uh...
How many times has he had this dream?
Any news on the Cargo Crew?
They've been recruiting.
Sounds about right. Cargo Crew only works when they've got enough people.
The Cargo Crew member who came here said that the situation on the train has gotten better.
...Is that so?
Are you going back, then, now that things are better?
I can't go back now. Ashlar is still hunting me. There is no place for me on the train.
Noan lowers his head inside the shaking carriage. The ghosts of his past also fall silent.
Did we really make the correct choice?
Even if Asslam is changing for the better... even if the future we dreamed of will one day come true...
What is the point of it... when none of you are here anymore? What's the point of me staying here?
He questions himself and the phantoms before him.
Shouldn't I... go find you?
You've got something you still need to do, haven't you?
What?
You haven't found me yet.
I'll be waiting for you at City 074, Noan...
I gave you the details and the route, right?
...Summer.
What's wrong?
Will you tell me if you're really alive?
But I've been here the whole time.
Except I know that...
...This is just a dream.
Why are you still fiddling with the wound above your eye?
It's almost been a year, and your wound still hasn't fully healed. You have to stop picking that scab, or you'll blind yourself eventually.
...It's been a year already?
Yeah.
I think you should see a psychiatrist. You can't keep checking if you're awake this way every time. Something's gonna go wrong eventually.
...I'm sorry.
Is there a reason... you came here today?
Oh. Recruitment asked me to talk to you since we know each other.
You've been here for almost a year.
She emphasizes again.
What's your plan? You can't keep doing odd jobs here and there.
The money from the young Construct allowed Noan to recover in the base for half a year.
After his wounds healed, Noan started performing random chores for the base like a Bumblebee.
He looked after the greenhouse, cleaned the streets, fixed the roofs, and even traveled beyond the base to scavenge for useful parts from broken machines.
As long as the job did not demand precision and skill, Noan would complete it on time, no matter how foul the work was.
Still...
Don't you think that kid is weird? When did he show up?
I don't remember either. He's one of the doctor's patients, I think. Started helping out after he recovered.

Helping out? "Sure." The kid does most of the chores for nothing but rations, so guess what happened to Old John? He got rejected again! He's going to die out there if he can't find a base with work he can do!
What can you do about it? The boss likes the kid and says he does four people's worth of work on his lonesome. Recruitment can't hire more people even if they want to.
What do you expect? I wouldn't hire some old man if I could have a hardworking young lad working for me!
Isn't the Cargo Crew recruiting as well? Kid could have tried to work on the train even if he didn't have any professional skills.
Maybe escorting cargo is too dangerous for his taste?
Tch. What a coward.
We have some positions available for full-time employment, but those are all senior roles.
You're too young to be working these odd jobs... like those desperate elderly folks. You've got choices.

Sigh. That Construct back then just said he ran into you on his way when the train didn't have a place for more wounded, but he never said anything about what would happen afterward. Is it possible for you to return?
I'm not trying to kick you out... I'm just wondering if you have better plans. Of course, you can stay here if you don't.
I know... Thank you, Doc.
Have you thought about where to go?
I have. I'll be leaving tomorrow.
...That quickly? You're not pushing yourself too hard or doing it out of spite, are you?
I'm not. Don't worry.
In that case, don't forget to get your pay for the last six months at recruitment tomorrow. At least get some food for the road.
And stop picking your scab no matter where you go, you hear me?
Got it, Doc. Thanks.
Noan takes his heavy backpack the next day, setting off on his own as the people from the base watch on.
He soon joins the Scavengers, traveling back and forth between cities and slowly heading toward City 074, where Field disappeared.
Then, one day, as the winter snow melts again and the weather gets warmer, Noan runs into a familiar figure in an empty alleyway unexpectedly.
So you're still alive, huh?
Don't you remember? This is the second time we've met.
It's been too long. I heard about what happened on the train. Foiled by a mole, huh? Didn't see that coming.
I suppose losing was inevitable when you guys were forced to fight before you were prepared.
I think Ashlar is still searching for the survivor core members. Judging from the way you look, I guess you aren't going back anytime soon, are you?
He cannot go back, indeed.
What about you? Why aren't you at the base, Bethe—
Don't call me that!
There is immediately a scowl on her face.
That old bastard...! Bethe lied to me about being my grandfather all these years!
Mr. Bethe isn't your grandfather...? But you two did look similar...
Shut up! I have nothing to do with Bethe anymore—I never should have. Don't call me by that name again.
...Bella... what happened?
I don't want to talk about it. Either way, I can't go back now, and that base doesn't concern me anymore.
Where are you going, then?
I'm going to find my mother... I just found out that she's still alive. She escaped the old bastard when I was very young, so I don't know where she is right now.
What about you? Where are you heading?
City 074.
On foot? You're properly mad, aren't you? How long will that take?
One or two years, I suppose.
You... Forget it. Not that there's something better to do.
Do you want to go together? I'm only searching for my mother on the way, after all. Safety in numbers and all that.
Oh, right. I never asked your name.
You were doing business with the Cargo Crew, and you don't know my name?
They only ever called you "Captain", " Four-Eyes", "Googly", or "Rachel's boy."
...When did anyone call me "Googly"?
How could I remember what you were called when there were so many people and nicknames in the Cargo Crew?
The only thing I remember is the names of the "culprits" from the "official" report: Assad, Barbra, Noan, and Rachel herself. Is one of those names yours?
I don't have a name.
Even the cannon folders in games have a name like "Slime" or something. Why wouldn't you have a name?
You can call me Slime, then.
People only throw their names away when they want to forget their past. Are you one of these people?
Bella sighs, realizing that she is also talking about herself.
You shouldn't forget it. Even if what happened on the train took away everything, you shouldn't let go of the memories of them.
Memories...
I know they've been calling you a monster, Noan, but a monster doesn't have to be horrifying or doomed. You might not be able to get rid of that label, but still...
I hope you grow up to be just like "Shrek" and live happily ever after.
What about... Shrek? My mom used to call me Shrek.
Sure.
Bella can tell he is hiding something, but she does not press any further. She also has her own secrets she wants to keep hidden.
Right... I've got something I need your help with.

One of them has buried his past and future underneath one horrible winter, now an empty shell and a walking dead; the other has furiously hidden the shame of being lied to for 24 years, unwilling to let it be brought up.
Two people and their secrets begin their journey to City 074.
Don't you think you've gone too far?
On the 25th day after they started traveling together, the apathetic soul realizes he may still be able to feel anger.
What?
I'm trying to arrive at City 074, not spending the last 25 days drawing a portrait of your mom from your memories.
I need to find her, but I don't have a photo of her. Getting you to draw a picture of her sounds like a solid plan to me. And you owed me one, remember?
I haven't practiced drawing since I joined the Cargo Crew. There's no way I can satisfy your unreasonable demands.
I'm just asking you to raise her eyebrows.
You asked me to move them lower five minutes ago.
Can't you make them a little bit higher while you make them a bit lower? Why is it so hard for you to understand what I'm describing?
Noan takes a deep breath before adjusting the eyebrows with his pen once again.
How about now?
It... still doesn't feel right. Forget the brows for now. Can you make her eyes look a little to the left and a little to the right?
I remember that her hair was gentle and bountiful like ripened grapevines.
And her gaze was shimmering like ripples on a lake.
Noan takes another deep breath.
...Who told you I could draw?
Rachel.
Have you considered that she might be joking, and I have no idea how to even hold a pen?
That's not possible. She had a drawing you made when you were young in her bag.
And... where did you learn to describe a face this way?

Bella waves the book in her hand. It is a collection of essays about the author's reflections on life, and the first chapter is filled with passages that depict the beauty of the female lead character.
Her eyes were like apples kissed by gunpowder, reflecting the dusk that the abandoned swan missed...
The solitude captured inside Mona Lisa's frame painted the colors of her fingertips...
Noan slams the book shut and politely returns it to Bella.
I think my mom was right about compromising on things you're powerless to do.
I've decided to give up on drawing starting today. I will not fantasize about making a living out of it anymore.
Are you always this agonized when you create? Or is it just because you haven't practiced enough?
I am always like this.
But you still owe me one, and Rachel said she wanted you to keep drawing after you left the Cargo Crew, didn't she? I'm giving you the tools to fulfill your dreams!
Keep practicing. Hard work beats talent any day! I'm sure you can do it. So—
Change! Those! Brows!
It takes Noan 50 days before he finally completes the first picture Bella is happy with.
I told you you can do it.

We would've gotten here sooner if you had said "a wider gap between the eyes" and "naturally curly hair" instead of "make her eyes look to the left and right" and "her hair was like ripened grapevines."
What's wrong with that? I find your inner life much richer than before, unlike the walking dead that you were when I first ran into you.
...You did a good job reviving me by making me roll over in my grave.
He puts down his pen and stretches his sore fingers.
Stop complaining. Keep an open mind! Let's go!
Bella waves her hand with great panache, making her way toward the place they agreed upon 50 days ago.
Once a journey begins, time becomes a whirlwind passing by.
The two of them join the Scavengers, searching for supplies and information with their skills while helping each other on the way.

The painful memories from their past have been neatly tucked away within them, becoming secrets they never speak of. Not that they speak with each other often—they only talk when absolutely necessary.
They only start chatting again when the next winter comes, and they start talking about books they have read.
One of them loves manga, while the other loves self-help books, so their interests barely overlap. Still, they only start talking because of books.

Time passes, and the teenager Bella thought was awaiting his "growth spurt" has grown to the size of a young man. Only one thing has not changed—his nightmares still haunt him, and he will not stop picking his scab.

To keep his wound from getting infected, Bella has found a pair of windproof goggles with corrective lenses to replace Noan's shattered glasses. She chuckles when she sees him trying to scratch through the goggles.
Have you seen those cone-shaped collars people put on their pets to keep them from licking their injuries?
Do your self-help books teach you how not to sound like a jerk?
Bella means well, but Noan has since started to avoid sleeping after losing his way to separate dreams from reality. He is afraid of losing himself once again in his old dreams.
Worried, Noan often sits all night by himself until the sun rises. Lacking sleep, he starts struggling with their journey during the day after a while.
After seeing Noan pass out once during their travel, Bella has to start making sure he sleeps.
I wasn't expecting to be a mother this young. Can't you take better care of yourself?
...You're free to let me be.
Look, I'm not as good as an ex-Cargo Cargo Captain when it comes to handling troubles on the road, alright? Do you know how much harder it is for me to survive if you drop dead now?
Noan does not want to worry her, but he still struggles to sleep normally, so he ends up learning to pretend to snore.
He can only confront the long night peacefully if Bella is calmly asleep.
The tiring journey continues for a long time. They come across many ruins during countless sunsets, searching for the signs of life in dark, empty alleyways.
When the fireflies take flight in the forest on a summer night, Noan remembers an old melody he has repressed deep inside.
Only then does he learn to use his mechanical firefly to anchor himself to reality, and he finally finds respite from this prolonged torment.
